/COMMIT_MSG.message: What happens if you're migrating to/from a compute that is running the old code?

If the dest host is running the old code then during the rollback it will persist the stale instance object. 

This data inconsistency does not cause any end user visible side effect as such InstancePCIRequest will be updated again during the next move operation of the instance. But it is ugly that we have invalid data in the db and in the future some operation might want to depend on the fact that the data is in sync.
Same.
This part of the change only affect the conductor code the explicit save and the explicit rollback was both done in the LiveMigrationTask so this change does not affect the upgrade.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
I'm confused. This patch removes the persisting of the pci_device change in conductor, right? What changes are you expecting to refresh here?

The last sentence here makes it sound like calling save() on our instance might overwrite something in the database if we don't do this, but that will only happen if our instance object has recorded that field as dirty. Is there some situation where our field will be dirty and outdated? Can you specifically call out what field you're worried about here in the comment?

The instance object is coming from the conductor via RPC. The conductor changed the content of the InstancePCIRequest according to the dest host of the migration but did not persist it. Now if we do not refresh the instance object before we save it below then the InstancePCIRequest change will be persisted to the DB. We don't want to do that as this is a rollback scenario so the instance is not on the dest host.

We do want to dirty the pci_requests field of the instance object in the conductor so that if the migration finishes then that change will be automatically persisted to the DB.


I've added more details to the comment.

18:22 < dansmith> gibi: what about checking obj_what_changed() right before the refresh 
                  and asserting that it's either empty or just contains the pci request 
                  info and logging a warning if not?
18:23 < dansmith> gibi: in fact if you did that you could avoid the expensive refresh for 
                  everyone else if it's not SRIOV
18:23 < gibi> dansmith: I can do that. But I can also extend the refresh() call with an

18:24 < gibi> dansmith: OK. I will follow your suggestion and check obj_what_changed and 
              log a warning if we would drop other fields than pci
18:24 < dansmith> gibi: and avoid the refresh if nothing is changed yeah?
18:24 < gibi> yepp
18:24 < dansmith> cool

If I have to prepare for a future instance.save() then I can only re-generate the old pci spec by calling update_pci_request_spec_with_allocated_interface_name() (that will call placement) as the db already contains the value based on the destination host.

However I'm not sure I want to prepare my solution against a future change that might or might not happen (i.e. YAGNI). I added test coverage that will fail if a future dev adds an instance.save() to the code path. So it cannot be silently broken. The test_live_migrate_with_qos_port_abort_migration fails if I add an instance.save() before the instance.refresh().

I can do a selective refresh for the pci_requests to avoid big hammer refresh(). (But I still think that refreshing AZ is a good thing here)

Done a selective refresh() of the pci spec only

> So I tested the obj_what_changed() way but there is no record of
 > our InstancePCIRequest.requests[].spec change in any level in the
 > ovo.
 > 
 > Runing the func test test_live_migrate_with_qos_port_abort_migration
 > I observer the followings before the instance.refresh() call. Note
 > that in this test there is one InstancePCIRequest (one SRIOV port)
 > with a single pci spec.
 > 
 > * instance.obj_what_changed() -> {'flavor', 'availability_zone'}
 > * instance.pci_requests.obj_what_changed() -> set()
 > * instance.pci_requests.requests[0].obj_what_changed() -> set()
 > * instance.pci_requests.requests[0].spec['parent_ifname'] ->
 > 'host2-ens2'
 > 
 > Note that in this test host2-ens2 is a PF on the migration
 > destination host, host1-ens2 is the PF on the source host.
 > 
 > So while the spec contains changed data we want to revert, the
 > obj_what_changes() facilities cannot be used to detect if such
 > changes was made.

Okay and it looks like we always serialize/save that field on instance.save() whether it has changed or not :(

Either way, synchronization of the dirty flag(s) in the pci_request(s) object(s) definitely look to be broken.

 > The availability_zone was modified by the conductor live migration
 > task [1] as well to set the AZ of the target host of the migration.
 > So reverting that during the rollback is the logical thing to do.
 > 
 > The flavor being dirty is a more interesting thing. The flavor is
 > marked dirty because it is lazy loaded at rejecet_sev_instance
 > decorator [3] top of the compute.api.live_migrate call [2]. While
 > instance._obj_load_attr has a obj_reset_changes() call at the end
 > it has no effect on the dirtiness of the flavor field. Also right
 > after an instance.save() in the compute.api.live_migrate call [4]
 > the flavor is still marked dirty.

Potentially because nothing else is calling obj_reset_changes() on the flavor itself. ObjectField items are considered dirty if the inner object is dirty, and resetting is only recursive if you ask for it. That recurse-ability was a change in recent years which likely didn't permeate everywhere.

 > Logically the flavor should not change during a live migration and
 > looking at the flavor in the test it does not.  So I think we can
 > ignore that the flavor is dirty. That is a separate bug.
 > 
 > In summary I think calling a instance.reset() is necessary as

Do you mean refresh() here?

 > i) we don't know if the pci spec is changed or not
 > ii) there is no way to know what else is really changed due to
 > false positives in obj_what_changed()

I don't think this statement is true, because if instance.host or something like that was changed, it would be clearly visible. I agree that the flavor being marked as dirty is an issue, but that is clearly a recent regression due to the SEV work, even if the bug is in the lazy load code.

 > iii) if something is changed since the last instance.save() in the
 > compute.api.live_migrate call then those changes are due to the
 > anticipation of the new host of the instance and therefore these
 > changes needs to be reverted as the migration is rolling back
 > causing that the anticipated host change does not happen.

Part of what seems wrong to me here is assuming that the instance never gets save()d between starting and failing the live migration. Meaning, I get that may be the case today, but in the future, someone may add something in the destination path that, unrelated to pci_requests, needs to get save()d. So they call instance.save(), which stabs the new pci_requests in there and then makes this refresh do nothing. How can we protect against that?

So I tested the obj_what_changed() way but there is no record of our InstancePCIRequest.requests[].spec change in any level in the ovo.

Runing the func test test_live_migrate_with_qos_port_abort_migration I observer the followings before the instance.refresh() call. Note that in this test there is one InstancePCIRequest (one SRIOV port) with a single pci spec.

* instance.obj_what_changed() -> {'flavor', 'availability_zone'}
* instance.pci_requests.obj_what_changed() -> set()
* instance.pci_requests.requests[0].obj_what_changed() -> set()
* instance.pci_requests.requests[0].spec['parent_ifname'] -> 
'host2-ens2'

Note that in this test host2-ens2 is a PF on the migration destination host, host1-ens2 is the PF on the source host. 

So while the spec contains changed data we want to revert, the obj_what_changes() facilities cannot be used to detect if such changes was made.

The availability_zone was modified by the conductor live migration task [1] as well to set the AZ of the target host of the migration. So reverting that during the rollback is the logical thing to do.

The flavor being dirty is a more interesting thing. The flavor is marked dirty because it is lazy loaded at rejecet_sev_instance decorator [3] top of the compute.api.live_migrate call [2]. While instance._obj_load_attr has a obj_reset_changes() call at the end it has no effect on the dirtiness of the flavor field. Also right after an instance.save() in the compute.api.live_migrate call [4] the flavor is still marked dirty.

Logically the flavor should not change during a live migration and looking at the flavor in the test it does not.  So I think we can ignore that the flavor is dirty. That is a separate bug.

In summary I think calling a instance.reset() is necessary as 
i) we don't know if the pci spec is changed or not
ii) there is no way to know what else is really changed due to false positives in obj_what_changed()
iii) if something is changed since the last instance.save() in the compute.api.live_migrate call then those changes are due to the anticipation of the new host of the instance and therefore these changes needs to be reverted as the migration is rolling back causing that the anticipated host change does not happen.

Erno's question brings up an interesting point.  These were originally named something like import_container_formats, but then we decided it was better to use the shorter name, but in their own group.  We want this to be a different option for all the reasons Stuart outlined above, but is using the same name (albeit in a different group) going to be confusing for operators?

Thanks for the explicit response and the details Brian.

I was thinking the other way but please correct me if I'm wrong.

1. CONF.image_import.disk_formats (above)
2. CONF.image_format.disk_formats ( https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/b9ec22ca012e1bbeadf143c4c82415f940ceb645/glance/api/v2/images.py#L887-L890 )


The reason why I was thinking this should NOT be a disjoint set was the acceptable nature of the end result of the formats that are supported in the cloud. Basically, when I see the config opt above, I assume it is target_disk_format as given in http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html#value-discovery . 

If this config is use for source_disk_formats then I think we do not have an issue.

However, if we use it to define the target_disk_format then we result into a situation where an internal endpoint that allows Nova to upload an image using the /file endpoint allowing qcow2 (as Stuart points out in his example) and then operator decides to disallow the target_disk_format 'qcow2' in their publicly exposed endpoint to the user (to be able to import an image 'into' a qcow2 disk format) via. /import endpoint.


In the later case, the GET on  /v2/schemas/image will show inconsistent result. The reason is, target_disk_format never allows the user to keep the image as qcow2 into the cloud but nova has on the other hand allowed qcow2. The snapshots created using nova will have qcow2 value on the image. So, when a user validated their images using the schema (given the schema should reflect list of target_disk_formats in the /v2/schemas/image call) , they will see an image format on the snapshot that's not listed as acceptable on the image schema. This will break client side validation (say using warlock or similar tools).


---

Or may be, I interpreted this config option incorrectly as being a list of target_image_formats whereas the intent is to describe the source_disk_formats ?

Either way, this needs correction: 

* in the first case addition of an explicit config option called source_disk_format and help text explaining what ie means to the operators. removing this value for target_disk_formats.
* and in the second case, renaming this to source_disk_formats and adding explanation to existing config option that it is same as target_disk_formats.

@Nikhil - could you explain this some more? I'm not sure I understand.

On the one hand, we have the GET /v2/schemas/image response that populates the allowed container and disk formats from the "regular" container_formats and disk_formats config values.  They basically tell a user what values an end user can use to PATCH an image's container_format or disk_format (same for an operator).  But they don't tell you what will happen if, for example, you update a VHD with disk_format == 'vmdk' or something.

The formats here appear will appear in the "value discovery" response and also in the GET /v2/schemas/import response.  Thus I think they could present a disjoint set of container_format, disk_format values without interfering with the image-schema response.  So, for example, an operator might set these (the [image_import] options) to container_format=bare and disk_format=raw, even though when the image is stored, it will be as container_format=ova and disk_format=vhd.

Actually, now I understand your point, which is (assuming the situation I just described):

image-schema: only ova, vhd allowed
import-schema: only bare, raw allowed

Thus when an end-user creates an image, they can't put bare, raw for container_format, disk_format even though that's what they've got.

But, this is good, because the image record should describe what's actually stored, not what's submitted to the import process.  The import spec says that when an end-user creates the image record, they should leave these blank, or, if they are filled in, they will be overwritten by the import process.

So I think this is OK?  In order for the discovery call to be useful, it needs to tell the end-user what formats the import process will accept.  Basically, an end-user should know what he's trying to import, and be able to predict, based on the discovery response, whether what's submitted will be accepted or not.

This looks like a bigger issue to me.

The GET schema call that returns the images schema returns the disk and container formats based on the config value. While nova based /file endpoint values won't be returned, this needs to be well documented for operators to expose to end users.

This also entails that the image formats claimed to work in a particular clouds in the images schema is not holistic and if qcow2 isn't allowed using /stage and appears in on the image using /file , the GET schema will be wrong.

I think as far as Glance is concerned, we should keep this simplistic and allow only on config that describes the list of formats accepted in the cloud. If an operator decides to not support a particular using the /stage , they may choose to provide a better message at the /import call level.

What we're not supporting is on-demand image conversion, where the end-user supplies format X and says "give me format Y".  It may be the case that the operator, as part of the import operation, changes the disk_format or container_format of what the end-user supplied.  Thus, the source_* say, "this is what I will accept", and the target_* say, "this is how I store stuff".  But they don't indicate that the end-user can specify what will happen in the interval.

We could drop the target_* for MVP as long as we make it clear that there's no guarantee that your source_* properties are actually the way the created Image will be stored. (Sorry about the typo, first paragraph is about max bytes, second is about max time.)

I think we need to protect against both in the Glance code itself, or at the very least in the standard Glance deployment.  As far as how, naively it seems that we do something like this: spawn a thread to receive the upload, monitor it, and kill it if some condition (time, number of bytes uploaded so far) is exceeded using some appropriate exception that the thread is ready to handle gracefully.

Hi Brian,

> The idea behind max_upload_bytes

(typo? max_upload_bytes->max_upload_time')

I understand the 'why' of max_upload_time. (Wouldn't it be nice to drop connections/return 400 when we hit a time limit.)

What I'm not clear on is the 'how'. For example, is this something that we intend to happen in the glance code in some way? If so, how? Or is the intention that something outside of glance (eg networking hardware/software rate limiter) will be configured to enforce this? If the latter, then it would be good to clearly communicate to operators that this is advisory only.

With max_upload_bytes, I think we need to close the connection when the value is exceeded (and then delete the data).  We can't allow the upload to complete first because it could fill all the available space (at which point the connection is going to be closed whether we like it or not).

The idea behind max_upload_bytes was to prevent a really slow connection from hogging resources.  One of these wouldn't be a big deal, but if some joker did a large number of concurrent imports, it's possible that service could be denied to other users.  If we are able to limit the number of PUT /stage a particular user is allowed, that sort of mitigates this attack, as the attacker would have to steal a large number of accounts to make it happen, and if we also limit the number of concurrent PUT /stage across all accounts, then the DOS would only affect image import.

I guess what it comes down to is we need to decide: what are the types of protections that a reasonable operator would expect to be in place if the operator is encouraged to expose this functionality to end-users?  These are all missing from the current image-upload functionality.

Hi Brian,

Ok, that clarifies the intent here somewhat -- thanks.

I'd like to see us avoid blocking on this though.

In otherwords, not getting bogged down in how we do this before we implement a working /stage API.

I'd see us as implementing that first, and then adding the timeout logic "later". ie reach a point where our proverbial physics department can use import, and then bikeshed on the merits of implementing this in glance or elsewhere. Note: there are many non-upload related ways of holding connections open.

Do folks feel it's ok to have an v2/info/import resource saying glance-direct is available before the import stuff is implemented?

ie v2/info/import's goal is discoverability; to find out what/how you can import. If I queried this resource and was told glance-direct is supported I'd expect to be able to make a follow up call to upload the bits into Glance, but that's not the case yet.

Should this be an empty list for now?
Done
That's a good point, I'm inclined to agree that an empty list makes sense at this point.
typo

I hope I'm not understanding this right.

What are we envisioning this array could have? It seems like we're falling back to the same problem where end users, and application developers are going to have to deal with edge cases here based on what possible values a cloud could have here based on their deployment choices - which is defeating the purpose an API.

author.name: Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)

glance/api/v2/info.py.message: It would be nice if the import methods were clearly defined and restricted. If it's any old thing that a deployer hacks up we're back to the exact same problem of the task api, non-discoverable and deployer-determined methods. This should be restricted to the one or two import methods described in the blueprint, and those methods need to be implemented.
I do not mind keeping this patch having a Depends-On for the glance-direct call. We need to time these two to land at the same time.
I guess this : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/312653/2

What Stuart said.

This is all discussed in the spec (which is one reason it's so long!).  You can read this part for a quick summary:

http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html#summary-of-the-constraints-around-this-project

tl;dr: with a little help, I think we can make this look almost like a v1 import to the user, and even do some basic failure cleanup.


There may be some additional import_method-specific attributes required (such as scope of network access of indirect import) that should also be defined rather than be an arbitrary dict.

-----
Doug: But there would be no way for deployers to add other methods so clients would only have to deal with the 2 methods. Is that still the plan?

dt: That is my plan, the user sees two variants, where 'swift-local' is a special-case of indirect ('copy-from').  Signalling the available scope of indirect is the point of the above comment.  I really want OSC to only have two choices: --filename|--location for the user to specify the source of the bits to be imported.  (yeah, there may be additional blanks to fill in, but those two will be the switch).  And if I cared to parse URIs, supporting file:// would work too, but that's not quite as user-friendly.

-----
Morgan: My concern/confusion is this looks like it is not going towards "2 methods" but "2 methods and pluggable for anything else"

dt: I want that to be phrased "2 methods where one (indirect) may have vendor-specific characteristics" if there must be value-add options here.   Indirect can be a single method (from the user POV) if all of the desired "plugging" is handled in the URI: swift://, vmware://, https://, gopher://, etc  After all, that's why URIs have schemes...and users smart enough to upload images get that.

-----
Nikhil: Like I mentioned above, the feedback from security team has been that `copy-from-url` cannot be considered as a standard practice as it has assumptions around the setup of network, access permissions to the url, scrutiny of data flowing through the wires, etc. So, we would like to avoid the `copy-from-url` case to not be part of the RefStack tests. It needs to be supported by operators who intend to expose it for use case like that of "pulling an image from apps.openstack.org"

dt: I need to go read all of that security feedback for full context, at first reading, the major difference between direct and indirect to me is the network access required for the Glance process to fetch an indirect URL.  'copy-fron' appears to assume full Internet access, 'swift-local' appears to only assume Swift endpoints, which may be completely internal to the cloud deployment (risk of some internal exposure there!) and of course direct is receive-only from the server standpoint.  All of the other risk factors appear to be common for all import methods.  Oh, one other difference: for direct you have only the credentials used for the user as audit for 'who did this', for indirect you also have the source URL, both of which may be compromised in worst-case.
-----

Ideally there will be no scheme-specific (swift/vmware/whatever) bits in the clients to deal with those implementations.  Just as with disk_format and friends, the indirect import scheme can be queried and selected by the user with the exact same (client) code path.  Anything vendor-specific will not make it into OSC for example...

I also have the same worries as well. I'm not convinced this any better of a solution until Glance is enforcing a strict list of methods and Defcore can be sure to have a clear strict list of that's what it'll be testing.

I thought we agreed that glance would implement exactly 2 methods, uploading directly into glance and uploading to swift and pulling it back down. The swift method would not always be activated since not all deployments have swift, so we need the discovery mechanism. But there would be no way for deployers to add other methods so clients would only have to deal with the 2 methods. Is that still the plan?

@Morgan, @Doug:



> I am not sure I am reading this correctly, but it seems that you are advocating for a non-strict interface that could do many things, meaning the user of the API would have implementation-details changing how this interface works.


No, user will not have implementation details of how this would work. I am advocating that user will have to know what the available way to import is in a particular cloud, that will be returned as a response via this import_methods call.



> Making the list of methods highly variable, deployer/operator specific, and not well defined makes me nervous this is going to be another one of the interfaces that end users will need magic knowledge of what it means to consume. That "magic" knowledge is what is concerning us from a RefStack/Defcore/"Not Open Core" perspective.


I asked a bunch of people at the summit and the response was that as long as RefStack tests pass you don't have an interop issue. If a site supports either `glance-direct` or `swift-local` , you will not have an interop issue as that's what the RefStack tests should test and they will pass for the clouds.

The way we look at it, the RefStack list is defined as ['glance-direct`, `swift-local`]. We are going to accept additional implementation of the upload mechanism (which is a deal breaker for some clouds) (and also supports feature parity with v1) (and was asked by many operators during the v1 deprecation session) is `copy-from-url` where a user is expected to provide a http(s) url to import the data from a remote (sometimes non-trusted data source). 

As there are many deployment specific assumptions -- say you only allow internal http(s) locations, or you only allow https locations, etc, this needs to be a non-DefCore (non-RefStack) implementation of the upload/data-copy mechanism. What that means is, it should be a choice of an operator if they intend to support it based on the security, performance etc assumptions.

I was hinted at the request to support may be a vmware specific location for those deployments to help speed-en snapshots.

Where will the implementations live? -- all upstream. 

What are the plugins (I really really want us to avoid using this term, more so because I want to avoid working on another hour long response, something that's not professionally healthy.) -- a set of scripts that operator can run on image data that has already been uploaded to the staging area (example [2]). The scripts will run on the image data itself and will be opaque from user's POV. Also, tasks need to be configurable as a image introspection/conversion on one cloud can be totally different from that on the other. (These set of operations are opaque to the user.)

Can this be done? I do not see a reason why not. I followed the blog from Mark [1] to see if it is OK. 

[1] http://markvoelker.github.io/blog/defcore-for-devs/
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html#data-put



> I want us to be sure we're doing our best to not leak implementation details to the end user(s). 


From what I described above, you tell me if we are exposing implementation details and why so?



> I thought we agreed that glance would implement exactly 2 methods, uploading directly into glance and uploading to swift and pulling it back down. The swift method would not always be activated since not all deployments have swift, so we need the discovery mechanism. But there would be no way for deployers to add other methods so clients would only have to deal with the 2 methods. Is that still the plan?


I think we will work with openstackclient (not sure about others) to support other provisioning like copy-from. Since operators will only be able to use what is upstream, we will have a provisioning with client with that update. As of now, we only have been given 3 strong use cases -- `glance-direct` , `swift-local` , `copy-from-url` with the first and the third being more popular with small scale clouds and second being preferable with large scale one.

As far as, which methods would be activated is concerned -- I think if we are giving a choice on `glance-direct` or `swift-local` then only one of those needs to be activated at a site for the tests to pass. I would assume operators who are worried about their public facing endpoint being subject to attacks, the `glance-direct` would be switched off.

Or did I misunderstand?

I had clearly communicated the requirement of a `copy-from-url` use case on the import spec. 

Please take a look at comment on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232371/ with the following search attributes you can use to find that comment. Also a response from Flavio on the same PS indicating the accommodation of that use case:

"
Nikhil Komawar    Dec 8 1:37 AM
Patch Set 7:
"



> I would be 100% in support of that. If there is "pluggable" bits for "other things" I want to see a well defined interface so there isn't magic "oh and this method needs arg X" but "other method needs arg Y".

> My concern/confusion is this looks like it is not going towards "2 methods" but "2 methods and pluggable for anything else"

Like I mentioned above, the feedback from security team has been that `copy-from-url` cannot be considered as a standard practice as it has assumptions around the setup of network, access permissions to the url, scrutiny of data flowing through the wires, etc. So, we would like to avoid the `copy-from-url` case to not be part of the RefStack tests. It needs to be supported by operators who intend to expose it for use case like that of "pulling an image from apps.openstack.org"

---

Having said that, irrespective of the implementation the APIs will be upstream. Hence, they will have info for the client to know the expected requests/responses.

The optional attributes are well defined as well, as the current proposal is for the three use-cases.

I do not see a reason why, if we need to support a vmware specific url to pull the data from data source, we can't do it without letting the client know of the expected request/responses.

Even if the support is for more than `glance-direct` or `swift-local`, DefCore capabilities will require all clouds to expose either of the above two to get the branding approved so they will always be available (in interop clouds) to ensure clients work successfully.

---

Let me know if I've missed anything. I'd really like to avoid repeating the same arguments again. So, if the intent isn't clear even now, we need to setup a hangout of air or likes of it, for a conversation that can be recorded and be made publicly available. 

I appreciate your time and thank you for understanding.

We would love for Glance to make progress in this and many other required important directions.

This has been discussed quite a bit as part of the spec process.

My understanding is that two methods will be anointed for defcore:

1) put the bits directly into glance (if you've no swift)
2) put the bits into swift and tell glance where the object is (if you have swift)

To pass the defcore tests at least one of these two will need to be available.

No doubt other methods will probably be proposed (eg import from a URL) but that's outside the current scope. We'll need to think about whether we want to support other proposed methods, and if so, how we make it clear that they are 'alternative' and not necessarily interoperable.

@Nikhil,

I am not sure I am reading this correctly, but it seems that you are advocating for a non-strict interface that could do many things, meaning the user of the API would have implementation-details changing how this interface works.

Making the list of methods highly variable, deployer/operator specific, and not well defined makes me nervous this is going to be another one of the interfaces that end users will need magic knowledge of what it means to consume. I want us to be sure we're doing our best to not leak implementation details to the end user(s).

Thanks for bearing with me here, I appreciate the effort you are putting in to communicate the intentions.
OK, so maybe we should define the glance-direct method before merging this patch. Is anyone working on this?

I would say that Glance should enforce one of the two methods as described by the spec. 

But the import from url and likes of it are required by the operators that assume certain type of setup (for example more trusted, less secure for other cases).

So we cannot be stringent on what all operators will support, we can be stringent on glance-direct or swift-local as described by the spec. That will ensure the RefStack tests pass and you don't have a interop issue.

OTOH, we can't have an implementation that will restrict very important use cases for some of the operators for eg. pulling an image from apps.openstack.org

base/openssh/centos/meta_patches/openssh.message:
This was required to handle a scenario where sshd startup did not generate a pid file after a system reboot. This resulted in pmon stuck trying to recover the already-running sshd (pmond thinks it's not running because the pidfile doesn't exist, and sshd fails to start up again because of the running sshd owning the port).

We'll need to make sure that either this scenario no longer exists, or that this is already handled in some manner. A simple way to check may be to delete the pid file and see what happens.

networking_bgpvpn/neutron/services/plugi.message: Please donot filter here by tenant_id, because a shared network can be associated to multiple bgpvpns.
please use the tenant_id inside the bgpvpn for which you are disassociating.

Deepthi,
what if the database transaction write failed after precommit at the Neutron level?

In this case, we will be sending disassociation to the external entity while the association will come back intact into the neutron db..
router cannot be shared, but better to code networks/routers in an uniform way.

We have an issue to solve here: when PRECOMMIT_DELETE is called, we don't have a guarantee that the router/network will be deleted. It will be deleted only if no callback raises an issue.

I think we should use a POSTCOMMIT event.

Thomas, we cannot use POSTCOMMIT event because, by the time postcommit is received, network gets deleted from db and the cascade effect will remove refernces from bgpvpn's tables. This means I cannot get all bgpvpns which were associated with the network.

Since I use the same db context, from network deletion, for bgpvpn-association deletion, network deletion failure will also mean association is retained.

I have tested the above scenario, where in delete event failed after precommit.

Yes, I know using POSTCOMMIT is not trivial.

Let me expose why I think we still need to act only at POSTCOMMIT.
Let's assume the following:
- multiple callbacks are registers for network delete pre-commit:
  * service plugin foo
  * bgpvpn service plugin
- let's assume that on a given network delete pre-commit event, the following happens:
  * bgpvpn callback is called and the net association is deleted
  * foo callback is called and raises an Exception
- the network deletion is aborted due to foo callback having raised an exception
- we end up with the association deleted while the network wasn't deleted


I was thinking we could consider using the PRECOMMIT to augment the context with information on the network association(s) that correspond to the network that will possibly be deleted, and reuse this information at POSTCOMMIT time.
I think it is nicer to use @registry.receives, so that the  the registration and the callback itself are grouped in the code.

I think it would be better to not confuse "network association deleted via the API" and "network association deleted as a consequence of network deletion".

Couldn't we add a "on_network_association_cascade_delete" driver hook ?
(same for network and port)

Having a distinct hook will also allow a driver that does not need these events to ignore them.

networking_bgpvpn/tests/unit/db/test_db..message: why we removed tenant_id?.. may be we can retain it by giving a valid formatted tenant_id

Update of tenant id in bgpvpn causes, bgpvpn to be updated. But the bgpvpn-net-assoc continues to have old tenant id.

BGPVPN-net-assoc-create api restricts association if both bgpvpn and network does not belong to same tenant id. So we have a silent bug here.

Our network pre_commit_delete handler code filter associations by bgpvpn's tenant id and this causes association retrieval to fetch empty results as tenant ids are different.

I updated the tests due to above reason, but the bug exists.

Thomas, is there a reason why update of bgpvpn with new tenant id is allowed?

Is there any service impact before the controllers are rebooted?

I don't think that leaving the system in a state where a restart of the apiserver pod could take the system out of service is acceptable. What order to the components need to be restarted in, in order to avoid a loss of service. Can we automatically restart the impacted pods without doing a lock/unlock?

The old configurations used by k8s master component pods will not be updated untill reboot or pods killed.

The only impact is that if the apiserver pod on the active controller exited accidentally before reboot, the new configuration will be updated and the certs used by apiserver will not align with other components, which leads to failure, then a reboot or killing other pods could resolve this.

So, the admin should reboot the controller asap once the certs are renewed.

This alarm is not "expected" to be cleared automatically if any of the process goes to error, admin should manually check the certs status, renew them and clear the alarm. The case you mentioned is one of it, although this script won't be executed again, the alarm is still there to inform admin.

neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py.message:
please see the change. i do not think that the reset flag should be set to false. it should be deleted.
the reason i added in the try/catch was that i was concerned that the self.cache.get_network_by_id could raise an exception

Comments:
1. Regarding the reset of the flag:
 - we run over the configured keys (these are the existing networks). so this structure will not grow indefinitely. This is why I pop the value and do not set it to False.
2. No change needs to be made here:

    def get_network_by_id(self, network_id):
        return self.cache.get(network_id)

By default python will return None if the entry is not found. So we should be good
This is done in self.call_driver. There will be no exception thrown here.

Why do you need this? Instead of this, why don't you enable the flag [1] and return? This should not be blocking if we have a process in parallel processing the allocations (greenthread).

[1] self._network_bulk_allocations[network.id] = True
Do we want to check this is > 0, or use min=0 in the config definition?  I guess we don't always check in other code.

Does the order of these instructions allow for a race condition? I'm wondering if you should do the del first, allowing for new updates to arrive, and ensure that another reload will be scheduled after the next interval passes?

The sleep interval seems an arbitrary limit on how frequently the reload will happen, causing some reloads to be delayed and others to be accelerated depending upon when they are added to the work list, and when the sleep interval elapses. This makes me wonder if 1 second is a good choice to reduce the average latency in the general case, but still permit updates to accumulate?

What about this variation?

from eventlet import event
import eventlet
...
self._reload_allocation_networks = {}
self._reload_allocation_event = event.Event()
...
def _reload_bulk_allocations(self):
    while True:
        network_id = self._reload_allocation_event.wait()
        if network_id in self._reload_allocation_networks:
            del self._reload_allocation_networks[network_id]
            network = self.cache.get_network_by_id(network_id)
            self.call_driver('bulk_reload_allocations', network)
            eventlet.greenthread.sleep(0)
...
        self._reload_allocation_networks[network.id] = True
        self._reload_allocation_event.send(network_id)



As written, all reload_allocations should be asynchronous in near real-time, where the time to complete the reload_allocation ends up being the time to accumulate other work. Although, Possibly the sleep(0) is too short to allow other work to get scheduled.

Just a thought... in the end, I think a 1 or 2 second bulk_reload_interval might be a good default choice that allows some work to merge before being actioned.

as 'tcp' or 'unspcified'

I don't think this will work. This will only return the protocol number if it's one of the protocol numbers that appears as a value in that map. If it's not a value in the map, it tries to look it up using it as a key. If there is a protocol that doesn't appear in the map, like 1121, then this method will return "unspecified", which isn't correct.

Either example-1 or example-2 in [1] are what I intended at the previous patch set. i prefer example-1 because example-2 could have too much change too.

How do you think of? 

1: https://gist.github.com/bloodeagle40234/eabe4f46f7bd986a88a31711b34fd833

I changed _build_version_id to _format_timestamp to make it a bit clearer that it's a timestamp..

I wanted to make sure it's clear that _build_versions_object_name and version id sysmeta use the same formatted timestamp.  (rather than duplicating the code like in example-1 ... it's only one line though hm...)

I prefer current name rather than _build_version_id if _build_versions_object_name uses it. it's clearly internal timestamp.

On the other hand, i suppose, you have right question if "timestamp can be id or not".

For now, i don't have clear answer. I guess it depends on the use case of version id. You say as "swift3 needs to know the version id even after it is restored, but right now there is no way to get the version id." in the commit message so more clear constraint for the swift3 use case. (e.g. how do we want the id to identify?)

Could you describe or point out the swift3 patch which wants this patch to use? I could help you to consider.

I think we might be able to satisfy both (keep version-id on restore *and* preserve it when re-archived) by doing

 get_resp.headers.setdefault(ver_id_header, self._format_timestamp(ts_source))

instead of an unconditional set...

I think version id should be consistent when objects are archived or restored. But using x-timestamp as version id can't achieve this feature. For example, suppose there is a versioned object with a name 003abc/ts1, if we restore it and then archive it again, it becomes 003abc/ts2.

In my opinion, we should store a random unique string in sysmeta header as version id when objects are created in swift3.

An object first gets a version id when it is moved to the archive.  The version id is part of the object name (e.g. 006object/123456789.000000 where 123456789.000000 is the version id).  If this gets restored because the current object is deleted, we lose the version id.

S3 allows users to get objects by version id even after an object is restored.  For example, GET /bucket/object?versionId=123456789.000000 should work regardless of whether this versioned object is in the archive or is the current object.  This already works if the object is in the archive, but we don't know the version id of the current object, so I tried save the version id in sysmeta. 

The relevant patch in swift3 is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/436570/

I'm open to different approaches, please let me know if you have more ideas :D

... but we maybe want to be doing the version-id-setting here instead. As soon as versioning gets enabled, all new PUTs need a version-id for S3 compat, right? So something like

 req.headers.setdefault('x-timestamp', Timestamp.now().internal)
 req.headers.setdefault(ver_id_header, req.headers['x-timestamp'])
 return app

and then we let that hang around as we copy back and forth between containers.

We might want to do something more akin to _update_x_timestamp for that first line, though; see https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.20.0/swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py#L539-L554

neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall.message: It's strange that we query the ovs port by port id here when we handle multiple ports but elsewhere (in _initialize...) when we handle a single port. It would be cleaner if we did both at the same place (either here or there, but at the same place). For example _initialize_egress_no_port_security would take one or more items of the same type.

"_initialize_egress_no_port_security" is called from:
- process_trusted_ports
- update_port_filter
- prepare_port_filter

The problem of modifying caller methods is that those methods are agent.FirewallDriver abstract methods implementations. Update and prepare methods only accept one port, unlike "process_trusted_ports". Is not that easy to change the firewall API.

IMO would be enough something like:

    if ovs_ports:
        ....

but that is only nitty nit :)

By default ovs_ports is None. In this case, we need to retrieve the port information individually because no information was given (L760).

But https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670162/4/neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/firewall.py@670 can return an empty list. In this case we need to execute this branch.

specs/ussuri/add_backup_id_to_volume.rst.message:
the property

(The reason why I want you to avoid saying that it's a "new" property is that it's not really a new volume property, it's just a piece of volume metadata.  Maybe what I say below will make this more clear.)

Instead of these, you can say:

Once added to the volume metadata, the ``backup_id`` will appear on any API response that displays volume metadata:

* the volume-show response (GET /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id})
* the volume-list-detail response  (GET /v3/{project_id}/volumes/detail)
* the volume-metadata-show response (GET /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/metadata)
* the volume-metadata-show-key response (GET/v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/metadata/{key})

Instead, you can say:

None.  The volume-show, volume-list-detail, and volume-metadata-show responses are currently defined to contain a ``metadata`` element that is either JSON null or a JSON object consisting of a list of key/value pairs.  The ``backup_id`` will appear in this list for appropriate volumes, but this respects the current API and does not require a new microversion.

The same holds for the other volume metadata calls.
You need a blank line before line 33 or sphinx won't recognize this as a list.
I think this will have to be indented two spaces (to begin under the 't' in the line above), or sphinx won't know that this is a continuation of the list item.
I think it would be a good idea to explain why there's no API impact.  (See my comment here on PS 13.)  In particular, you want to state explicitly that no new microversion is needed.

This should describe the behavior when a backup is restored over an existing volume -- presumably backup_id gets updated to a new value?

Presumably when restoring from a chain of incremental backups, backup_id is set to the last incremental backup used for the restore?

Should document that since users will be able to arbitrarily set this metadata field to whatever they want, it can't be relied on for programmatically analyzing where volumes came from etc. for admin/auditing purposes.
This is a good point.  End users can do whatever they like with this field, which is fine for the use case stated in this spec, but doesn't extend to any kind of auditing use case.

Let's put something here so we don't forget.

* Release note should point out that since this is stored in the volume metadata, it can be modified or removed by end users, so operators should not rely upon it being present for administrative or auditing purposes.

* Add a similar note somewhere in the admin docs, probably a page about volume metadata written by Cinder (which may not currently exist).  In addition to reminding admins that end users can overwrite volume metadata, should explain how to read the 'src_backup_id' (particularly the part you mention on line 30 about what id is used when restoring from incremental backups).

kernel/kernel-modules/mlnx-ofa_kernel/ce.message: Since we are updating this patch, can we also debrand the TiS name here?

I thought we had agreed that for the purpose of these cleanup/debrand we should just do it as we touch the patches as there is never time to go back and do the sweep.  We have been doing that all along with the various centos 7.x and 8.x update work.

If I agreed to that, I take it back.  It's a very crappy way of doing things and a bad habit to get into, polluting bug reviews (which are bad enough to do as it is) with other unrelated stuff.  Hit me with a launchpad to do kernel module cleanup and I *will* go through them all and do it.
If there isn't already one, we should create a storyboard story for this cleanup, and just do it. Since there'd be no functional changes, the test effort would pretty much just be "does it build?"

I usually don't like mixing janitorial tasks with bug fixes, as other open source developers have admonished me for doing that in the past, as it pollutes the code diff with stuff not directly related to the problem/bug.  Janitorial cleanup should be done in its own commit, and I'm not adverse to doing such a sweep through the kernel modules at some point.

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rb.message:
If i understand the bug correctly, the problem is that you get an InvalidArgument exception when you call image.update(key, val) when key already has value val.  This test makes sure that if you start with everything "on", the correct ones are turned "off".

I think in addition to this test, you may want to add one that has journaling, fast diff, object map, and exlusive lock already "off" and make sure _enable_multiattach() doesn't explode and that they're still "off" after the call.  (Maybe mock image.update_features() to always raise InvalidArgument?)
-1: Journaling is not set on L2501-L2505, so this case will never happen, right?

-1: When we know it's only one call we should use assert_called_once_with:

        image.update_features.assert_called_once_with(
            RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING |
            RBD_FEATURE_FAST_DIFF |
            RBD_FEATURE_OBJECT_MAP |
            RBD_FEATURE_EXCLUSIVE_LOCK,
            False)

-1: This is not correct, in most cases we are no longer passing a single feature:

  if feature & (RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING | RBD_FEATURE_OBJECT_MAP)
Wouldn't it be better to check what the call to the update method was instead of changing it?  After all the raise shouldn't happen anymore.
?: Why aren't we setting the image features?
-1: This isn't any different than the previous test.
-1: This would only work if we only set 1 feature, not if we set multiple.
?: Why don't we just check the values that are passed to the update?

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: This has to be made a collections.OrderedDict if order matters here.

-1: If I understand this correctly we could have skipped a value from setting it to False on L786 (because it was already False) yet we saved it as part of the `saved_features`, which means that we would be setting it to True here and therefore restoring it wrong when doing the disabling.

Oh, thanks for the clarification!!

Then if that's the reason for the try...except clause, why don't we just drop the whole for loop and make a single call to update_features?

On driver's __init__ we do:
        self.MULTIATTACH_FEATURES = (self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING | 
                                     self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_FAST_DIFF |
                                     self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_OBJECT_MAP | 
                                     self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_EXCLUSIVE_LOCK)


And the whole _enable_multiattach function can be:
        vol_name = utils.convert_str(volume.name)
        with RBDVolumeProxy(self, vol_name) as image:
            image_features = image.features()
            change_features = self.MULTIATTACH_FEATURES & image_features
            image.update_features(change_features, False)

        return {'provider_location':
                self._dumps({'saved_features': image_features})}


And to disable we also wouldn't need a loop (L810-L817):
        change_features =  self.MULTIATTACH_FEATURES & image_features
        image.update_features(change_features, True)


Or am I missing something?

No, see line 806 combined with line 811.  We have the original bitmask; for each targeted feature in that bitmask, if it was enabled, we attempt to reenable it.  The unobvious bit is that update_features() *may* change other features in order to satisfy the request, so the try/catch addresses features that needed setting but were already set by update_features().  This goes for _enable_multiattach() as well.
nit: Creating this as an instance attribute on __init__ method means that we don't have to create the tuple each time.

-1: I don't see a reason to have this duplicated here, not only is it less efficient than having it in the __init__ method, but it also adds more code.

Why are we duplicating it? What am I missing?
?: Couldn't this be misleading if the error is a network connection issue on the update call?
See the above exception for rbd.InvalidArgument, that should take care of it.

Better use attribute notation so we know that volume_type is not a dict:

  volume_type.extra_specs
Have you tried this in python3?

Is ANDing right with the multiattach exclusions? So it will only change things that are in the exclusion list? That seems like it conflicts with the naming of that.

Not sure if we need a comment here explaining what is being done better, or if I am just not getting it.

Yes, this is correct logic.  We acquire a bitmask of only the features changed from the enable call.  Here we reenable those features as this is the "disable_multiattach" method, so we're removing the exclusions that were applied as a result of the enable method.

I'm a little confused on this since from the commit message I thought it was saying InvalidArgument is actually OK since it will be raised if the flag is already set to what is being requested. So raising a driver exception looks like it will still cause a failure like it did prior to the change.

InvalidArgument would be valid for a single feature that had already been disabled as a dependency of another feature as a side effect.  But in this case we're making a single call and there should never be an InvalidArgument exception in that case.  If this happens, the operation has failed and there is no recovery.

Are these two _is_*_type changes related? It doesn't look like this actually changes anything, other than adding a debug log. But not sure I see how an exception can get thrown since the get call on extra_specs should just return None, and 'None == "<is> True"' should just return the expected False.

This failed to work in a recent devstack environment and dot notation should be fine for this OVO.  As extra specs are not guaranteed to be present, an AttributeError exeption is possible, which should be handled.

tools/deployment/common/005-deploy-k8s.s.message: Note this comment and the actual generation of the flag by minikube here: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e22ebe6efa06490a88ec990b13a79f60/log/job-output.txt#1007

Steve, if we use the systemd.resolved service, then the contents of /etc/resolv.conf will be dictated by the systemd.resolved local cached stub dns /etc/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf, which only contains 127.0.0.1:53
And any manual update of the /etc/resolv.conf will be irrelevant.
The problem is that the systemd-resolved stub dns is running locally on port 53 and so is the cluster dns.
Question is in ubuntu 18.04 should we use systemd-resolved service, or should we disable systemd-resolved service, and rely on statically configured /etc/resolv.conf instead for name resolution.

good catch! I thought I had removed this line. Must have been added as part of a rebase. I will remove this line. there should not be a soft link to /etc/resolv.conf.
Thanks.

I understand what you're saying - I did the work here to work around the move to systemd-resolved in 18.04.  The point is: even with what you're doing here, Minikube is still going to direct the kubelet to use /run/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf for dns configuration, no matter what you do.  This is built into the Minikube binary and will not change, full stop.  My question has been:  how do you plan to circumvent this?  I'm looking at other job runs in this repository, and I'm not seeing any issues with conflicts or failure in DNS resolution.  What exactly is this change fixing?

If there use of systemd-resolved service and configuration for name resolution and there is no way around it. I don't think this ps fixes anything, and I can abandon it.
I was using an older version of openstack-helm-infra to build the shipyard docker image, using bionic base image, the airskiff deployment failed on name resolution. I think now if I use your ps https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685775/ it should address my problem.
Also, not related to this, in Airship in a bottle deployment, I noticed that coredns pods are fails, because if we use systemd-resolved service is starts a local stub dns on the node listening on :53, which blocks any other dns service on that node, causing coredns/cluster-dns to fail due to port busy.

Well, that's not the entirety of the problem though.  Minikube will automatically pass in the path of the resolv.conf file managed by systemd-resolved, regardless of whether you disable the service or not. Please see the links I provided in my other comment. You can also see the flag on the kubelet in the systemd output as part of the post run jobs: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e22ebe6efa06490a88ec990b13a79f60/log/primary/system/systemd-cgls.txt#277
